children.subject: As long as the replacement units you take in the Fall will be graded (and of course you take 16A/B), this seems totally fine to me.
You may want to check with your ESS advisor as the deadline to PNP technical classes has passed. You may need to submit a petition.
You will need to check with ESS; this may not be possible at this time.
I will contact my advisor. Thank you!

I am a current EECS sophomore taking Math 54. Is it possible for me to P/NP 54 this semester and take the replacement technical units in the Fall? 
(I was planning to take the replacement technical units anyway, this decision is more to lighten my current semester load so I can focus more on other classes)
I've taken Physics H7C without Math 54 and it was fine. As long as you're fine with wave equations and matrices, I think it's okay.

Now that Math 54 (or Math 110) will no longer be required for EECS majors because of the overlap with  EE16A and 16B, does anyone know if EE 16A and 16B will substitute as the prerequisite for Physics 7C?  Currently Math 54 is listed as a prerequisite for Physics 7C (or can be taken concurrently).
Yes, DS8 can count for this.
Does this mean any technical courses in those departments? Specifically, can Data 8 take care of this requirement?
This must be a unique course, not used for the 20 units of upper division EECS
If I end up taking 24 units of upperdiv CS courses, including Data 100, can I use Data 100 to satisfy these technical units?
Yes, units not used to fulfill the 20 UD EECS requirement could be used for this one.
Does Data 100 (CS c100) satisfy both the CS upperdiv requirement as well as these 4 technical units? Also, does IEOR 135 satisfy these technical units?

check out the sample transfer plans on the EECS website, it give you a better feel for how the department expects transfers to deal with this change. The web page can be found here:

https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/transfer-prereqs/sample-programs

Does it also affect transfer students? I have taken Linear Algebra & Differential Equations at CCC which is equivalent to Math 54, and how would this change affect me and students who share the same situation? Thank you!

If you transferred in to EECS and already took the equivalent of Math 54 in community college, the change in requirements has no negative impact relative to how things worked previously (you can still count Math 54 towards those technical units).  If anything, I think the situation overall is a bit better since if you took Math 54 and understood it well, you can take 47D to make up the circuits material and then go straight to 16B the following semester.

(Things are slightly different if you are an L&S transfer, but overall I think the conclusion with regards to the net impact is the same.)
How would it affect us then?

history.content:
Dear EECS majors; 
Pending final approval from the College of Engineering Undergraduate Study Committee and COE Faculty:
Effective June 1st, 2017, the EECS department plans to remove the requirement of Math 54 or Math 110 for all EECS majors (including current students). In its place, students will instead take four technical units. The reason for this change is that the EE16A/B sequence (which is already required for EECS students) covers 90% of the content included in Math 54 (and in fact expands beyond Math 54 in certain areas, specifically SVD and DFT). Please note that students who have already taken Math 54 or 110 will have satisfied the requirement for these four technical units.
Technical units may include courses from the following departments: Astronomy, Chemistry, Earth and Planetary Science (other than 170AC), Integrative Biology, Molecular Cell Biology, Physics, Plant & Microbial Biology, Mathematics, Statistics, Data Science, and any Engineering department (including EECS). 
These technical units cannot include: any course taken on a P/NP basis; courses numbered 24, 39, 84; BioE 100; ChemE 185; CS C79, 195, H195; Des Inv courses (except Des Inv 15, 22, 90E, 190E); Engin125, 157AC; IEOR 95, 172, 185, 186, 190 series, 191, 192, 195; ME 191AC, 190K, 191K.

#pin
